reviews.review_msg: There are SO many readings/week, even tho some are "recommended". in order to get a good grade, he expects you to read them too... (100+ pages/week). His take home final is another 7-8 page paper, which is v diff than what he described it in the syllabus (a 6 page answer to 2-3 essay questions). WAY TOO MUCH WORK FOR A 3 CREDIT/200-Level CLASS

Shane is a very clear prof with high expectations and a great wealth of knowledge. Lecture slides are really packed with information though, so that's a little overwhelming. but his lectures are very clear and to the point. Also, his TA Elizabeth for his class is an angel.

I would not encourage anyone to take a class with him. He is unclear about his expectations and has poor organizational skills in terms of the structure of his lectures and the overall course. His expectations are high and does not appear to understand that you're taking other classes. He also spends an ungodly amount of time talking about himself.
I think I made it through one full lecture in the semester. They are pontless as he rambles unclearly. It's impossible to know what he wants in papers but exams are easy.

Amir is really excited about the topics and passionate, however extremely disorganized. He kept changing the structure of assignments and lecture was hard to sit through. He is a good person, but not a strong teacher. He was flexible, but sometimes led to last minute pointless changes in the course. Also, exams are easy, but not well written..

Awesome.  He gives you to two weeks choose the term paper topic, two weeks to submit the proposal and two weeks to write your paper. Relates the weekly readings to real world and connects the dots. However, this was an evening class at 5:30 :(

Maybe it is because it was his first time teaching 235 but he is the worst prof i've ever had. Lectures are pointless and have no relevance to the exam, he has trouble explaining concepts he wants students to explain, and there is very little notice for assignments. The course content for CMNS 235 is great, but I never take a class with Amir.

Amir is a really nice and helpful prof, but I think his willingness to help stems from the fact that his lectures are confusing and moderately pointless. Everything was based off of the textbook, and the questions on the exams were so concentrated that there was little room for error. Really passionate, but equally unorganized.

He is a really good professor.I've done Journalism course with him and would love to take another course with him.He is very caring, gives really good feedback, explains with understandable examples, makes everything easy to grasp. he is a Journalist so he shares his pov and the concepts by relating them with himself.very good professor.GO FOR HIM.

The best CMNS prof I've had. Offers his insight as a journalist to the course; clear grading criteria; student interest guides projects and even course topics covered. He went out of his way to give thorough feedback, encouragement and even recommend journalists and academics he thought would be of personal interest to me based on my responses.

Kathy cares deeply for her students and wants them all to do well in her classes. Her lectures are incredibly clear and you know exactly what to expect for the midterm and final. Everything is available on WebCt. Lots of readings, but the readings are interesting and well related to the course! Highly recommended.

Most helpful prof I have met so far in SFU, and knows what he is talking about at all times. If you do your weekly readings you will definitely do great on the midterm. The midterm consist of multiple choices, short answers, and essay. Final is a take home final.

While the course material was pretty dry at times, Dr. Gutstein was a great lecturer and had a good sense of humour and was one of the more realistic professors in the Communications Department. Just a very nice class to sit and listen in.

takin this course w. him was super helpful and knowledgeable.altho he is kinda slow and silent, but the way he organizes lecs and content is very neat and easy to follow up. take it if u r interested in newsps and news. itz really good.
I wish he'd find a way to make his lectures more lively. That droning sound wasn't the lights, it was all of us snoring.

Well... I'd say it's a good way to just skip lecture but do good in the course... he doesn't use a mic and he reads right off his powerpoint - then he sends the notes to you through E-mail... what's the point then????

The most exciting thing about his lectures was seeing what crazy aloha shirt he wore. Seriously, though, a really nice guy with an immense wealth of knowledge but his lectures were as exciting as watching grass grow.
His lectures were unclear and hard to follow. His arguemenst were vague, and supported by his own bias. I would recommend not taking a course by him if you could avoid it. It is a waste of time.

One of my very few favorite profs in SFU. Nice guy. Well-prepared, understable, interesting lectures with real-life examples - unlike other CMNS courses which are full of abstract theories. Got a good grade. Recommanded.
Really smart! If you're interested in journalism, he's your man!
Very knowledgable, responsive to questions, sincere
Expert Sun/Province basher.  Tends to drift sometimes.
